For use cases where a list of historical records needs censorship resistance against state-level attacks, it's definitely one (very inefficient) potential solution. But I would argue that the #of products/services that need that scale of security model is very small.

Now if you want to venture into things like decentralized trust - yes, Nakamoto PoW-based consensus was innovative in its application to securing this linked-list we call a blockchain. But a) PoW consensus itself isn't "blockchain" and b) it has a very limited #of use cases

A blockchain is a cryptographically verifiable data structure that allows for transparent auditing of historical records. It is akin to an immutable linked-list, and nothing more. Distribution, consensus etc. is all layered on top of that and should not be labelled "blockchain"
Unless you're willing to say that VR/AR and chat bots are also "like the very early days of the internet", you have a very misaligned perception of what a blockchain does.
